bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, June 23, 1899

div1.p: Kean considers sending his family back to the United States because of the risk of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, June 23, 1899
div1.opener:
Chief Surgeon's Office.
HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY CORPS.
Gen Lee's
Quemados, Cuba
June 23rd
My dearest Mum -
div1.p:
Your charming letter
has just come and been
read and I will send
you a line in answer
before I take it home to
Louise, so that you may
know just how far I can
influence her to carry out
your wishes. I am much
touched at your appeals
to see the girls- I was away
from them myself for six
months last year & know
how it is. And then I have
the instinct of object obe-
dience to my Mum, still
left over from the days of my
engagement.

Now I cant order Louise
home because she knows
that I think that she and
Martha run no more risk
at present in Quemados
than in Morristown. By
August malaria may be-
gin to show up and then
they will have to go. Of
yellow fever where we are
I have no fear at all.
It does not leave the big
towns much in Cuba, the
in the U.S. it chases around
the small towns quite a
bit. I have asked her a
number of times if she
does not want to go to
you at Morristown, and
she says always- yes, in
August if you will promise to take a
leave in September"- Now I will give
her your letter, and offer her the money
to go if she so decides but that is all I
can do at present. We were apart so
much last year that I have waxed
a bit selfish and Mr Kips claims
do not appeal to me a bit tho I am
gratified at their fondness for Louise.
I do not know but that I may be follow-
ing the great bulk of the regular army
to the Phillipines before long, and so
I am as I say some what greedy about
the girls. But if Louise is inclined to
go now I shall tell her that I approve
of her decision and think it best.

We may all be coming north for
all I know - for I am doing my
best to make it hot for some very
influential people, whose opposition
& obstinancy in sanitary matters here
has given us an entirely needless
typhoid epidemic. And the simplest
way out of the matter may be to get
rid of me. As I wrote to Reed the
times demand a martyr & I am like
Bro. Rabbit willing to be thrown into the briar
patch.

Goodbye dear Mummy. I will answer your letter soon.
But don't get rattled about your girls.
